Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: From the Distal Demonstrative to a Stance Marker: On na in Mandarin Chinese Conversation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
All languages have words to indicate entities that are being referred to. These words (e.g. this and that), known in linguistics as demonstratives, are typically used to focus the hearer's attention on entities in the speech situation. Over time, some of these words evolve and may develop various kinds of new functions such as connectives and hesitation signals. Despite the universality of demonstratives across languages, demonstratives differ in how they change and why they evolve in certain ways. Although demonstratives have long been a key research topic in linguistics, we know surprisingly little about how demonstratives and demonstrative-derived pragmatic markers are used in spontaneous face-to-face conversation. This is due to the fact that the most commonly used genres in linguistic analysis are written discourse and oral narratives rather than spoken discourse. The results and transcriptions will help applied linguists and L2 educators develop more effective materials for teaching Mandarin Chinese, a critical language designated by the U.S. government. The project database will enhance the infrastructure for language-related research and education, and will contribute to the training of students.

This dissertation project recognizes the methodological limitations in previous text-based analyses and investigates how the distal demonstrative na 'that' is used in Mandarin Chinese everyday conversation from a discourse-pragmatic perspective. Apart from its canonical usage as a distal demonstrative, na has various kinds of extended and nuanced discourse functions. This project sets out to identify and classify different uses of na, with a special focus on its previously overlooked non-referential discourse pragmatic functions. More specifically, it will uncover sequential contexts, functional accounts, and positions of na using both a quantitative approach and qualitative analysis. The primary goal is to offer a systematic analysis that accounts for all the occurrences and functions of na by speakers in actual everyday conversation. The secondary goal is to shed light on a better understanding of robust similarities and subtle language specific variations in the grammaticalization and/or pragmaticalization of demonstratives, particularly the non-deictic uses of pragmatic markers derived from demonstratives. This dissertation project will contribute to a deeper understanding of a common human language phenomenon with fresh data and from an interactional perspective.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Demonstratives are words like this and that in English. As common expressions in everyday language, they have long been one of the key research topics in linguistics. Across the languages of the world, they play an essential role in communication. Demonstratives are historically very old and often exhibit interesting patterns of change over time. Apart from their canonical use (i.e. refer or point to an object), they also have a wide range of extended and nuanced functions, particularly in natural conversation. For instance, in addition to functioning as definite articles, fillers, and connectives, demonstratives can also be used to convey different shades of speaker emotion and attitude. Despite extensive research on demonstratives, we still have a lot to learn?especially with regard to how speakers use them in spontaneous interactions and natural settings.

This project sought to investigate how the word na, which literally means 'that', is used in Mandarin Chinese conversation. More specifically, it identified 1) the discourse-pragmatic functions of na and the relative frequencies of its different usages in Mandarin Chinese conversation; 2) contexts in which na typically appears and reasons speakers use na in those contexts; 3) how the position of na in dialogues interacts with its discourse-pragmatic functions; and 4) interrelations among different usages.

The data for this project were collected during the Co-PI's fieldwork in Mainland China in the summer of 2019. 59 native speakers of Mandarin Chinese stratified by age, sex, and education background were recruited. 44 hours of face-to-face casual conversations were video-recorded. 23 hours of conversational data were transcribed word for word, yielding approximately 400,000 transcribed Chinese characters.

Major findings of the project are:

1). For the turn-initial and turn-medial, utterance-initial instances of na, previously well-attested reference-tracking usage is very much marginalized. The predominant non-referential na on the other hand, is routinely used by speakers to register that the current turn/utterance is built from a prior turn/utterance, nevertheless there is a contrast or shift in stance or focus.

2). In direct contrast to the turn-initial and turn-medial, utterance-initial na, the turn-medial, utterance-medial na instances by and large exhibit a homogenous referential function. Apart from instances where na is embedded in reported speech, the rest is used endophorically, either as an anaphora to refer to the previously mentioned constituent or proposition, or as a cataphora that is co-referential with a later element in discourse.

3). The non-referential uses and the referential uses of na are closely related. The more pragmaticalized endophoric use, particularly discourse deictic uses give rise to the non-deictic usages because of their backward-looking function. The turn/utterance-initial na, when used discourse deicticly, is a backward-looking demonstrative keeping track of a chunk of the preceding discourse; when used non-referentially, is a special linking device with both backward-looking and forward-looking properties. Looking backward, it acknowledges what has been produced before, operates on it while projecting a next action due?a question or a disaffiliative move.

The findings from this project, in the form of a PhD dissertation and peer-reviewed academic articles, will contribute to our understanding of a broad spectrum of functions that a distal demonstrative can fulfill. At the same time, results on the relative frequency of each use can help elucidate the processing and development of linguistic structure. Starting from the uses of demonstratives, we can also better understand and characterize their relationship to other varieties of indexicality. Methodologically speaking, this study shows the importance of integrating conversation structural notions such as turns and turn-constructional units in linguistic description. This empirical study also has clear pedagogical implications. The Mandarin Chinese na is a high frequency lexical item. Identifying and classifying different uses of it can help develop effective materials for teaching Mandarin Chinese as a foreign/second/heritage language. In addition, the project transcripts also form a database constituting of authentic examples of a wide range of grammatical items and pragmatic practices produced by native speakers. This can facilitate L2 educators to create textbooks and authentic teaching materials that are both educational and contextualized, hence better address learners? pedagogical needs. Another broader impact of the project is that it resulted in the training of 4 student research assistants in linguistic fieldwork and data transcription. One of the students has received an offer of admission to graduate study in a linguistics program this year.
